etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin disrupt- ‘broken apart’, from the verb disrumpere

definitions: interrupt (an event, activity, or process) by causing a disturbance or problem

examples.text: a rail strike that could disrupt both passenger and freight service

shortDefinitions: interrupt event, activity, or process by causing disturbance or problem

definitions: drastically alter or destroy the structure of

examples.text: if an explosion of volcanic steam had formed the crater, the blast from below would have disrupted the underlying rock

shortDefinitions: drastically alter or destroy structure of

definitions: (of a company or form of technology) cause radical change in (an industry or market) by means of innovation

examples.text: our 3D printing technology is disrupting the traditional manufacturing industry

shortDefinitions: cause radical change in (industry) through innovation
